questions.question: Extracellular concentration of a positive ion (with valency = 1) is 100mmol/L and itsintracellular concentration is 10mmol/L, the potential across the membrane using Nernstequation is (mV).
questions.explanation: The potential of a positive ion across the membrane using Nernst equation is +60mV.6261ZEMF (millivolts)=x logConcentration insideConcentration outsideOMARROWWhere, z is valency in the formula.Deriving the numerical value:EMF = 61/1 *log 10/100= 61The choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and denominator does not matterbecause the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and not the sign ( +/- ).Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1 and log (10/100)=-= 1. Hence, changing the numerator anddenominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same.Deciding the sign/charge: A positive ion with greater concentration extracellularly will try todiffuse inside the cell. A positive intracellular potential is required to prevent this. Hence thesign/charge (potential) is positive (+).Hence, the potential across the membrane using the Nernst equation is +60mV (the closestanswer chosen).

questions.question: What is the effect on the cellular membrane when the extracellular concentration of K+ isdecreased?
questions.explanation: When the extracellular concentration of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), there is increasednegativity of RMP.RMP predominantly depends on the diffusion of K+ from inside to outside the cell. This diffusiondepends on the concentration gradient with the inside of the cell having a larger concentration ofK+ ions. When the extracellular concentration of K+ decreases, the concentration gradient for K+rises. Therefore, more K+ ions diffuse out of the cell. This leaves the inside of the cell morenegative relative to the extracellular space. This increases the negativity of the RMP, leaving themembrane hyperpolarised.
